Subgroup

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Cyclic group
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
Commutative Ring
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
Sum of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Image of a Ring Homomorphism
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Localization of a Ring

Given a ring $R$ and a multiplicative system $S \subset R$, the localization $S^{-1}R$ (or $R_S$) is the ring of fractions $ rac{a}{s}$ where $a \in R$ and $s \in S$, under an equivalence relation defined by $ rac{a}{s} =  rac{a'}{s'}$ if there exists some $s'' \in S$ such that $as's'' = a'ss''$.
Length of an A-module
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
Ring Homomorphism of Finite Type

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Dihedral Group

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The sum of ideals is defined in the context of a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an ideal is and subsequently what the sum of ideals is.

The image of a ring homomorphism is defined in the context of rings and ring homomorphisms. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring homomorphism is and subsequently what the image of a ring homomorphism is.
Localization of a ring is defined in the context of rings. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what localization of a ring is.

The length of an A-module is defined in the context of modules over a ring A. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an A-module is and subsequently what the length of an A-module is.

A ring homomorphism of finite type is defined in the context of rings and ring homomorphisms. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring homomorphism is and subsequently what a ring homomorphism of finite type is.

The Galois group of a finite field extension is defined in the context of field extensions, which are a specific type of ring extension. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a field is and subsequently what a field extension is.
